_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    MFA Bulk Plant - Levasy
Location:    36906 E. 24 Hwy, Levasy, Mo.
Contact:     Bill Collier
Phone:     816-650-3122


1. The Facility Policy

MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA Bulk Plant in Levasy are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Fort Osage Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of liquid fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. The facility also handles pesticides products.

The facility has (1) 30,000 gallon storage tank and (1) 18,000 gallon storage tank. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport delivery truck holding approximately 50,000 pounds. The facility also has (52) 1,000 gallon nurse tanks for product distribution. 

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;
    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b

. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community 
        right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 
        1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. The facility has been evaluated for improvements to meet the K61.1-1999 ANSI Code and upgrades will be made in the near future.
